data.title: Out-of-the-box color picker
data.body:
To improve user experience when working with styling in CSS files we plan to add a colour picker.

There are current implementations of colour picker in extension marketplace but they are heavy-weight and do not form part of the core code.

data.title: Smoke test build status indicator
data.body:
To enable visibility of our automated smoke builds we should create an extension that indicates about the current VSTS build status in VS Code status bar. 

**Requirements:**
General-purpose extension. 
Reusable for other VSTS builds, not only targeted for VS Code.

data.title: Uninstall extension did not remove previous betas

milestone.title: Backlog

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.0
- OS Version: Win 10x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install extension beta build of any extension via "..." / "Install from VSIX...";
2. Wait until this extension will get new public version (VSCode will update your beta till latest build) and reload VScode;
3. Uninstall this extension and reload VSCode

Expected: VSCode without our uninstalled extension

Actual: VSCode with beta build of the extension. With auto update it immediately start to update => You can't uninstall it until do not turn off auto updater.

data.title: Installer and Updater without administrator privileges
data.body:
Hello,

what about adding a feature to the installer that the installer recognizes it when the administrator permission request failed. When the request failed it should install VSCode into `%AppData%` like WebStorm (which I don't like) for example. With this installation it should be possible to use the integrated updater like a normal installation with administrator privileges.

So you have not to:

- check manually when updates were released
- update manually
- download the zip archive for portable versions

What to you think about that feature?

2. Open command palette and search for `Emmet: wrap with abbreviation`

What is alternative for Emmet commands?

data.title: Remember all UI state even for empty windows (fixes #207)
data.body: Introduces a new setting `window.restoreWindows: 'all' | 'folders' | 'one' | 'empty'`. Deprecates `window.reopenFolders`.

data.title: Support Sublime-Text-style selection transpose
data.body:
([Way back in December](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/3776#issuecomment-267736625), @rebornix said in #3776 that this was a good idea to contribute to core, but I never really got around to it until now...)

This commit adds Sublime Text 3's other transpose behavior to the `transpose` action: Transposing selections.

`transpose` will behave as before if all selections are empty. But if at least one selection is non-empty, `transpose` will instead transpose the contents of the selection, replacing the contents of selection 2 with selection 1, selection 3 with selection 2, and so on until selection 1 is replaced with the contents of the last selection.

This allows quick swaps, for instance, you can double-click on one word, Opt+double-click on another word, and press Ctrl+T to swap them.

VS Code currently has two Transpose actions:

- `editor.action.transposeLetters`
  "Transpose Letters" (bound to `^t` by default)
- `editor.action.transpose`
  "Transpose characters around the cursor" (not bound to anything by default)

These are very subtly different: `transposeLetters` does nothing at the end of a line, while `transpose` transposes the last character to the other side of the line break (in a clone of Sublime Text's behavior).

(Note that neither of these matches the emacs/macOS behavior, which is to transpose the last two characters of the line.)

This behavior has been added to `transpose` rather than `transposeLetters`, because `transpose` seems to both be a less specific name, and because it was designed for Sublime compatibility.

data.title: Select multiple lines with ALT+CLICK+Scroll?
data.body:
Awesome ALT+CLICK to create multiple cursors, but how to select multiple lines quickly? 
Like IDEA i can select multiple lines by hold ALT+CLICK and Scroll.
Scroll when hold ALT+CLICK is NOT select contents, it's just create cursors step by step.

Case below, batch replace the char 'g' to y

```go
var (
	keg1 = 0x0001
	keg2 = 0x0002
	keg3 = 0x0003
	keg4 = 0x0004
)
```

data.title: Typo in for callstack viewer implementation - presenationHint should be presentationHint
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.13.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 CU

There's a `t` missing in `presenationHint`.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Look at the code:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/debug/electron-browser/debugViewer.ts#L547
2. Look at the vscode debug protocol here:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/84e2178de0aafc0cacc767204de7baf64161db44/src/vs/workbench/parts/debug/common/debugProtocol.d.ts#L1099

and here:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/84e2178de0aafc0cacc767204de7baf64161db44/src/vs/workbench/parts/debug/common/debugProtocol.d.ts#L1127

Also note that stackFrame.source only supports `emphasize` and `deemphasize` according to the protocol.  It is stackFrame itself that supports the `subtle` and `label` hints.

data.title: tmux pane_current_path is duplicated
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.13.0 (1.13.0)
- OS Version: MacOS 10.12.5
- extensions: occurs even when I run code with `--disable-extensions`

Steps to Reproduce:

1. put this in `.tmux.conf`:
```
set -g pane-border-format "#{pane_index} #{pane_current_path} "
setw -g pane-border-status bottom

```
2. start a terminal in VSCode
3. in the terminal start tmux
```
tmux new-session -s test
```

Now, in the pane status line I expect to see the current path, e.g. `-0 /Users/klas.mellbourn ---`. 

Instead it looks like this `-/Users/klas.mellburn-0 /User/klas.mellbourn ---`. 
It seems that the current path and a dash is prepended to the expected pane title.

This occurs for both `bash` and `zsh`.

This occurs _only_ for the first pane. If I split the tmux session into to panes beside each other, the second pane gets the expected title `-1 /User/klas.mellbourn --`. However, the title for the second pane is positioned incorrectly horizontally. It is offset to the right by the size of the string `/Users/klas.mellbourn` as if tmux did not expect it to be shown.

This occurs _only_ within Visual Studio code. The pane title behaves just as expected in terminals (such as `iTerm` or the built in `terminal`) outside Visual Studio Code.

data.title: [Request] Option to format Javascript flat ternary expressions
data.body:
Example of how multiple js ternary expressions are currently formatted:
```
var a =
    foo ? bar :
        baz ? qux :
            boop;
```

Requested preference to format flat js ternary expressions:

```
var a =
    foo ? bar :
    baz ? qux :
    boop;
```

reference: http://eslint.org/docs/rules/indent#flatternaryexpressions

data.title: Intellisense with word wrap breaks below the wrap when using vscodevim.vim
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro

Steps to Reproduce:

0. Have the vscodevim.vim extension.
1. Activate Word Wrap.
2. Have a line that is long enough to wrap.
3. Intellisense works above the wrap but stops working below it.

data.title: Terminal erratic behavior + duplicate path after updating VSCode
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.0 (1.13.0)
- OS Version: macOS Sierra - 10.12.5
- **using ZSH**

Steps to Reproduce:

1. updated to latest VSCode version
2. open terminal instance
3. look at path (see image)
![vscode-path](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1163408/27049687-47535b50-4f6d-11e7-8bfb-a631f64e02d2.jpg)
4. when interacting with terminal (typing/clicking) there is a flicker and text flashes while the path looks to correct itself... but always returns to its duplicated state.
